Award.AwardTitle: Hazards SEES Type 2: Modeling to Promote Regional Resilience to Repeated Heat Waves and Hurricanes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Communities are interested in becoming more resilient to weather extremes but often lack the tools and resources to fully understand the problems and make good decisions. This lack of understanding is understandable given the complex and interrelated nature of the impacts from extreme events. Communities need to design solutions for infrastructure management, land use planning, public health, and emergency management, understanding how each is related to the other. In areas that are subject to repeated events, the problem is exacerbated. In this project, an interdisciplinary team of researchers will develop an integrated model, the Integrated Hazard, Impact, and Resilience Model to better understand the impacts of repeated hurricanes and heat waves on regional vulnerability and resilience and use the model to develop approaches for improving resilience to these repeated hazards. The team integrates expertise in individual and organizational behavior, economic modeling, climate science, infrastructure engineering, hazard modeling, public health, and spatial landscape analysis. The work on this project will be grounded in and integrated through systems modeling. The goal of the project is to significantly advance the understanding of the impacts from hurricanes and heat waves on the vulnerability and resilience of regions over time and the tools and resources available to help regions better prevent repeated hazards from becoming repeated disasters.

The mid-Atlantic region will be the case study for this project, grounding the work in a critical region of the U.S., one that has a growing population facing increasing threats from weather extremes. The team will also have strong international collaborators, helping to make sure the work has broad applicability to other areas of the world. As part of this project, a set of undergraduates, masters, and doctoral students as well as postdoctoral scholars will be trained in trans-disciplinary hazards research and modeling. This cadre of students and researchers will form a critical resource for the nation, helping to improve regional resilience to repeated hurricanes and heat waves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on two main goals. The first was to develop a better understanding of how repeated natural hazards impact a community and how behavior in a community changes its vulnerability to future natural hazard. The second goal was to develop better methods for helping interdisciplinary teams work together in an integrated manner. The research team made many other substantial research advances within their individuals disciplines, but this report focuses on these two main cross-cutting goals. To help achieve the first goal, the team created models of the impacts of repeated hazards on communities that included models of the hazard, the damage the hazard caused and who within the community experienced damage, how individual households made decisions about strengthening their houses after the hazard, if people moved out after the hazard, and community decisions such as whether or not to install hazard protection measures such as levees to protect against a flood. This work focused on hurricanes (wind damage, power outages, and flooding), river flooding, and tsunamis. This work showed that behavior at the individual household level interact with community-level decisions to significantly change how a community evolves over time as that community faces repeated hazards over a period of years. This then changed the vulnerability of that community to future hazards. These findings help to improve hazard modeling and the understanding of hazards because many hazard models ignore the impacts of behavior and decisions between hazard  events on the vulnerability of communities to subsequent hazards.

 

To help achieve the second goal the team developed a way to use a model called an agent-based model, a simulation model that includes individual people, households, and organizations, to provide a way for the interdisciplinary team to better collaborate. This approach allowed team members from different disciplines to come together around a single object ? the agent-based model ? and use this to communicate across disciplines, to talk about data and models across disciplines, and to together develop deeper understanding and modeling of the impacts of repeated hazards. The team also collaborated closely with a team of researchers in Japan, helping to strengthen both international collaboration and interdisciplinary collaboration.

 

One other key outcome of this project was extensive involvement of students and postdoctoral trainees. The project involved three postdoctoral researchers, nine PhD students, and nine undergraduate researchers from diverse disciplines and backgrounds. These students and postdoctoral researchers gained valuable training and experience in hazards research and interdisciplinary research methods. Three of these individuals became faculty members by the end of the project, one started a company, others pursued STEM careers in industry and at U.S. national laboratories, and others continued on to further study in graduate school.
